speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. A street.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Cornets. Enter CORIOLANUS, MENENIUS, all the Gentry, COMINIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, and other Senators

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Tullus Aufidius then had made new head?

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: He had, my lord; and that it was which caused

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Our swifter composition.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: So then the Volsces stand but as at first,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make road.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Upon's again.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: They are worn, lord consul, so,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: That we shall hardly in our ages see

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Their banners wave again.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Saw you Aufidius?

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: On safe-guard he  came to me; and did curse

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Against the Volsces, for they had so vilely

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Yielded the town: he is retired to Antium.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Spoke he of me?

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: He did, my lord.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: How? what?

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: How often he had met you, sword to sword;

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: That of all things upon the earth he hated

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Your person most, that he would pawn his fortunes

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: To hopeless restitution, so he might

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: Be call'd your vanquisher.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: At Antium lives he?

speaker: LARTIUS
text_entry: At Antium.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I wish I had a cause to seek him there,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To oppose his hatred fully. Welcome home.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Enter SICINIUS and BRUTUS

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Behold, these are the tribunes of the people,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The tongues o' the common mouth: I do despise them;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: For they do prank them in authority,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Against all noble sufferance.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Pass no further.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Ha! what is that?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It will be dangerous to go on: no further.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: What makes this change?

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: The matter?

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Hath he not pass'd the noble and the common?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Cominius, no.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Have I had children's voices?

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Tribunes, give way; he shall to the market-place.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The people are incensed against him.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Stop,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Or all will fall in broil.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Are these your herd?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Must these have voices, that can yield them now

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And straight disclaim their tongues? What are

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: your offices?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: You being their mouths, why rule you not their teeth?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Have you not set them on?

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Be calm, be calm.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: It is a purposed thing, and grows by plot,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To curb the will of the nobility:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Suffer't, and live with such as cannot rule

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Nor ever will be ruled.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Call't not a plot:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The people cry you mock'd them, and of late,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When corn was given them gratis, you repined;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Scandal'd the suppliants for the people, call'd them

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Time-pleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Why, this was known before.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Not to them all.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Have you inform'd them sithence?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: How! I inform them!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: You are like to do such business.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Not unlike,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Each way, to better yours.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Why then should I be consul? By yond clouds,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Let me deserve so ill as you, and make me

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Your fellow tribune.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: You show too much of that

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: For which the people stir: if you will pass

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: To where you are bound, you must inquire your way,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Which you are out of, with a gentler spirit,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Or never be so noble as a consul,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Nor yoke with him for tribune.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Let's be calm.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: The people are abused; set on. This paltering

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Becomes not Rome, nor has Coriolanus

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Deserved this so dishonour'd rub, laid falsely

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: I' the plain way of his merit.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Tell me of corn!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: This was my speech, and I will speak't again--

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Not now, not now.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Not in this heat, sir, now.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Now, as I live, I will. My nobler friends,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I crave their pardons:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: For the mutable, rank-scented many, let them

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Regard me as I do not flatter, and

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Therein behold themselves: I say again,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: In soothing them, we nourish 'gainst our senate

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The cockle of rebellion, insolence, sedition,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Which we ourselves have plough'd for, sow'd,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: and scatter'd,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: By mingling them with us, the honour'd number,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Who lack not virtue, no, nor power, but that

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Which they have given to beggars.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Well, no more.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: No more words, we beseech you.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: How! no more!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: As for my country I have shed my blood,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Not fearing outward force, so shall my lungs

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Coin words till their decay against those measles,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Which we disdain should tatter us, yet sought

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The very way to catch them.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You speak o' the people,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As if you were a god to punish, not

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: A man of their infirmity.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: 'Twere well

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: We let the people know't.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: What, what? his choler?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Choler!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Were I as patient as the midnight sleep,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: By Jove, 'twould be my mind!

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: It is a mind

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: That shall remain a poison where it is,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Not poison any further.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Shall remain!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Hear you this Triton of the minnows? mark you

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: His absolute 'shall'?

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: 'Twas from the canon.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: 'Shall'!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: O good but most unwise patricians! why,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: You grave but reckless senators, have you thus

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Given Hydra here to choose an officer,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That with his peremptory 'shall,' being but

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The horn and noise o' the monster's, wants not spirit

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To say he'll turn your current in a ditch,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And make your channel his? If he have power

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Then vail your ignorance; if none, awake

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Your dangerous lenity. If you are learn'd,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Be not as common fools; if you are not,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Let them have cushions by you. You are plebeians,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: If they be senators: and they are no less,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: When, both your voices blended, the great'st taste

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Most palates theirs. They choose their magistrate,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And such a one as he, who puts his 'shall,'

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: His popular 'shall' against a graver bench

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Than ever frown in Greece. By Jove himself!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: It makes the consuls base: and my soul aches

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To know, when two authorities are up,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Neither supreme, how soon confusion

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: May enter 'twixt the gap of both and take

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The one by the other.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Well, on to the market-place.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Whoever gave that counsel, to give forth

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The corn o' the storehouse gratis, as 'twas used

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Sometime in Greece,--

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Well, well, no more of that.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Though there the people had more absolute power,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I say, they nourish'd disobedience, fed

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The ruin of the state.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why, shall the people give

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: One that speaks thus their voice?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I'll give my reasons,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: More worthier than their voices. They know the corn

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Was not our recompense, resting well assured

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That ne'er did service for't: being press'd to the war,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Even when the navel of the state was touch'd,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: They would not thread the gates. This kind of service

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Did not deserve corn gratis. Being i' the war

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Their mutinies and revolts, wherein they show'd

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Most valour, spoke not for them: the accusation

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Which they have often made against the senate,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: All cause unborn, could never be the motive

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of our so frank donation. Well, what then?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: How shall this bisson multitude digest

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The senate's courtesy? Let deeds express

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: What's like to be their words: 'we did request it;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: We are the greater poll, and in true fear

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: They gave us our demands.' Thus we debase

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The nature of our seats and make the rabble

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Call our cares fears; which will in time

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Break ope the locks o' the senate and bring in

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The crows to peck the eagles.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Come, enough.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enough, with over-measure.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: No, take more:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: What may be sworn by, both divine and human,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Seal what I end withal! This double worship,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Where one part does disdain with cause, the other

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Insult without all reason, where gentry, title, wisdom,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Cannot conclude but by the yea and no

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of general ignorance,--it must omit

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Real necessities, and give way the while

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To unstable slightness: purpose so barr'd,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: it follows,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Nothing is done to purpose. Therefore, beseech you,--

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: You that will be less fearful than discreet,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That love the fundamental part of state

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: More than you doubt the change on't, that prefer

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A noble life before a long, and wish

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To jump a body with a dangerous physic

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That's sure of death without it, at once pluck out

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The multitudinous tongue; let them not lick

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The sweet which is their poison: your dishonour

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Mangles true judgment and bereaves the state

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of that integrity which should become't,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Not having the power to do the good it would,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: For the in which doth control't.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Has said enough.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Has spoken like a traitor, and shall answer

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: As traitors do.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Thou wretch, despite o'erwhelm thee!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: What should the people do with these bald tribunes?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: On whom depending, their obedience fails

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To the greater bench: in a rebellion,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: When what's not meet, but what must be, was law,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Then were they chosen: in a better hour,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Let what is meet be said it must be meet,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And throw their power i' the dust.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Manifest treason!

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: This a consul? no.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The aediles, ho!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter an AEdile

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let him be apprehended.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Go, call the people:

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Exit AEdile

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: in whose name myself

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Attach thee as a traitorous innovator,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: A foe to the public weal: obey, I charge thee,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: And follow to thine answer.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Hence, old goat!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Senators,  and C We'll surety him.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Aged sir, hands off.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Hence, rotten thing! or I shall shake thy bones

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Out of thy garments.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Help, ye citizens!

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Enter a rabble of Citizens (Plebeians), with the AEdiles

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: On both sides more respect.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Here's he that would take from you all your power.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Seize him, AEdiles!

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: Down with him! down with him!

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: Senators,  and C Weapons, weapons, weapons!

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: They all bustle about CORIOLANUS, crying

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: 'Tribunes!' 'Patricians!' 'Citizens!' 'What, ho!'

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: 'Sicinius!' 'Brutus!' 'Coriolanus!' 'Citizens!'

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: 'Peace, peace, peace!' 'Stay, hold, peace!'

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: What is about to be? I am out of breath;

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Confusion's near; I cannot speak. You, tribunes

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: To the people! Coriolanus, patience!

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Speak, good Sicinius.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Hear me, people; peace!

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: Let's hear our tribune: peace Speak, speak, speak.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: You are at point to lose your liberties:

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Marcius would have all from you; Marcius,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Whom late you have named for consul.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Fie, fie, fie!

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: This is the way to kindle, not to quench.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: To unbuild the city and to lay all flat.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: What is the city but the people?

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: True,

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: The people are the city.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By the consent of all, we were establish'd

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The people's magistrates.

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: You so remain.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: And so are like to do.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: That is the way to lay the city flat;

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: To bring the roof to the foundation,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: And bury all, which yet distinctly ranges,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: In heaps and piles of ruin.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: This deserves death.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Or let us stand to our authority,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Or let us lose it. We do here pronounce,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Upon the part o' the people, in whose power

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We were elected theirs, Marcius is worthy

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of present death.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Therefore lay hold of him;

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Bear him to the rock Tarpeian, and from thence

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Into destruction cast him.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: AEdiles, seize him!

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: Yield, Marcius, yield!

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Hear me one word;

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Beseech you, tribunes, hear me but a word.

speaker: AEdile
text_entry: Peace, peace!

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: [To BRUTUS]  Be that you seem, truly your

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: country's friend,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: And temperately proceed to what you would

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Thus violently redress.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Sir, those cold ways,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That seem like prudent helps, are very poisonous

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Where the disease is violent. Lay hands upon him,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And bear him to the rock.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: No, I'll die here.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Drawing his sword

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: There's some among you have beheld me fighting:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Come, try upon yourselves what you have seen me.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Down with that sword! Tribunes, withdraw awhile.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lay hands upon him.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Help Marcius, help,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: You that be noble; help him, young and old!

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: Down with him, down with him!

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: In this mutiny, the Tribunes, the AEdiles, and the People, are beat in

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Go, get you to your house; be gone, away!

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: All will be naught else.

speaker: Second Senator
text_entry: Get you gone.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Stand fast;

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: We have as many friends as enemies.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Sham it be put to that?

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: The gods forbid!

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: I prithee, noble friend, home to thy house;

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Leave us to cure this cause.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: For 'tis a sore upon us,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: You cannot tent yourself: be gone, beseech you.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Come, sir, along with us.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I would they were barbarians--as they are,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Though in Rome litter'd--not Romans--as they are not,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Though calved i' the porch o' the Capitol--

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Be gone;

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Put not your worthy rage into your tongue;

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: One time will owe another.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: On fair ground

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I could beat forty of them.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: I could myself

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Take up a brace o' the best of them; yea, the

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: two tribunes:

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: But now 'tis odds beyond arithmetic;

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: And manhood is call'd foolery, when it stands

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Against a falling fabric. Will you hence,

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Before the tag return? whose rage doth rend

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Like interrupted waters and o'erbear

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: What they are used to bear.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Pray you, be gone:

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: I'll try whether my old wit be in request

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: With those that have but little: this must be patch'd

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: With cloth of any colour.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Nay, come away.

speaker: COMINIUS
text_entry: Exeunt CORIOLANUS, COMINIUS, and others

speaker: A Patrician
text_entry: This man has marr'd his fortune.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: His nature is too noble for the world:

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: He would not flatter Neptune for his trident,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Or Jove for's power to thunder. His heart's his mouth:

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: What his breast forges, that his tongue must vent;

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: And, being angry, does forget that ever

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: He heard the name of death.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: A noise within

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Here's goodly work!

speaker: Second Patrician
text_entry: I would they were abed!

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: I would they were in Tiber! What the vengeance!

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Could he not speak 'em fair?

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Re-enter BRUTUS and SICINIUS, with the rabble

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Where is this viper

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: That would depopulate the city and

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Be every man himself?

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: You worthy tribunes,--

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: He shall be thrown down the Tarpeian rock

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: With rigorous hands: he hath resisted law,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: And therefore law shall scorn him further trial

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Than the severity of the public power

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Which he so sets at nought.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: He shall well know

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: The noble tribunes are the people's mouths,

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: And we their hands.

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: He shall, sure on't.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Sir, sir,--

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Peace!

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: With modest warrant.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Sir, how comes't that you

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Have holp to make this rescue?

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Hear me speak:

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: As I do know the consul's worthiness,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: So can I name his faults,--

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Consul! what consul?

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: The consul Coriolanus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He consul!

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: No, no, no, no, no.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: If, by the tribunes' leave, and yours, good people,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: I may be heard, I would crave a word or two;

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: The which shall turn you to no further harm

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Than so much loss of time.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Speak briefly then;

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: For we are peremptory to dispatch

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: This viperous traitor: to eject him hence

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Were but one danger, and to keep him here

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Our certain death: therefore it is decreed

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: He dies to-night.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Now the good gods forbid

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: That our renowned Rome, whose gratitude

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Towards her deserved children is enroll'd

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: In Jove's own book, like an unnatural dam

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Should now eat up her own!

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: He's a disease that must be cut away.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: O, he's a limb that has but a disease;

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Mortal, to cut it off; to cure it, easy.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: What has he done to Rome that's worthy death?

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Killing our enemies, the blood he hath lost--

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Which, I dare vouch, is more than that he hath,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: By many an ounce--he dropp'd it for his country;

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: And what is left, to lose it by his country,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Were to us all, that do't and suffer it,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: A brand to the end o' the world.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: This is clean kam.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Merely awry: when he did love his country,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It honour'd him.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: The service of the foot

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Being once gangrened, is not then respected

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: For what before it was.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We'll hear no more.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Pursue him to his house, and pluck him thence:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lest his infection, being of catching nature,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Spread further.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: One word more, one word.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: This tiger-footed rage, when it shall find

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: The harm of unscann'd swiftness, will too late

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Tie leaden pounds to's heels. Proceed by process;

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Lest parties, as he is beloved, break out,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: And sack great Rome with Romans.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If it were so,--

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: What do ye talk?

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Have we not had a taste of his obedience?

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Our aediles smote? ourselves resisted? Come.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Consider this: he has been bred i' the wars

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Since he could draw a sword, and is ill school'd

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: In bolted language; meal and bran together

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: He throws without distinction. Give me leave,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: I'll go to him, and undertake to bring him

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Where he shall answer, by a lawful form,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: In peace, to his utmost peril.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Noble tribunes,

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: It is the humane way: the other course

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Will prove too bloody, and the end of it

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Unknown to the beginning.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Noble Menenius,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Be you then as the people's officer.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Masters, lay down your weapons.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Go not home.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Meet on the market-place. We'll attend you there:

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Where, if you bring not Marcius, we'll proceed

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: In our first way.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: I'll bring him to you.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: To the Senators

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Let me desire your company: he must come,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Or what is worst will follow.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Pray you, let's to him.

speaker: First Senator
text_entry: Exeunt
